[[Category:Pages for deletion]] [[Image:Imad_Latheef.jpg|right|thumb|Imad Latheef]] '''Imad H. Latheef''' is a professional Maldivian journalist. He is currently the foreign news editor, in Haveeru Daily news paper in Maldives. ==Early and personal life== Imad Latheef was born in the island of [[Meedhoo]] in [[Addu]] atoll. He had two sons and a daughter. ==Educational background== Latheef completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. {{maldives-bio-stub}} [[Category:Maldivian people]] [[Category:Maldivian journalists]] [[dv:{{PAGENAME}}]]

[[Category:Pages for deletion]] [[Image:Imad_Latheef.jpg|right|thumb|Imad Latheef]] '''Imad H. Latheef''' is a professional Maldivian journalist. He is currently the foreign news editor, in Haveeru Daily news paper in Maldives. ==Early and personal life== Imad Latheef was born in the island of [[Meedhoo]] in [[Addu]] atoll. Mr. Latheef's father Mr. Hassan Latheef worked as an elcetrician for the British Royal Air Force in [[Gan]]. He had two sons and a daughter. ==Educational background== Latheef completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. {{maldives-bio-stub}} [[Category:Maldivian people]] [[Category:Maldivian journalists]] [[dv:{{PAGENAME}}]]

Mr. Latheef's father Mr. Hassan Latheef worked as an elcetrician for the British Royal Air Force in [[Gan]]. He had two sons and a daughter. ==Educational background== Latheef completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. {{maldives-bio-stub}} [[Category:Maldivian people]] [[Category:Maldivian journalists]] [[dv:{{PAGENAME}}]]

[[Category:Pages for deletion]] [[Image:Imad_Latheef.jpg|right|thumb|Imad Latheef]] '''Imad H. Latheef''' ([[Dhivehi]]: ޢިމާދު ލަޠީފް ) ('''b.''' [[October 27]], [[1966]]), is a professional Maldivian journalist, columnist and a commentator. He is currently the foreign news editor, in [[Haveeru Daily]] news paper in Maldives. ==Early and personal life== Imad Latheef was born in the island of [[Meedhoo]] in [[Addu]] atoll. He married to Siyana Shafeeq in [[1985]], with whom he had a son. In [[1990]] they had a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. Latheef lives with his wife and children in Male’. Before his career as a [[journalist]] began, Latheef filled several private company posts. ==Educational background== Latheef completed his secondarys education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. {{maldives-bio-stub}} [[Category:Maldivian people]] [[Category:Maldivian journalists]] [[dv:{{PAGENAME}}]]

[[October 27]], [[1966]]), is a professional Maldivian journalist, columnist and a commentator. He is currently the foreign news editor, in [[Haveeru Daily]] news paper in Maldives. ==Early and personal life== Imad Latheef was born in the island of [[Meedhoo]] in [[Addu]] atoll. He married to Siyana Shafeeq in [[1985]], with whom he had a son. In [[1990]] they had a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. Latheef lives with his wife and children in Male’. Before his career as a [[journalist]] began, Latheef filled several private company posts. ==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]].Malé English School, Malé. Later he joined Majeediyya School where he did his secondary education. {{maldives-bio-stub}} [[Category:Maldivian people]] [[Category:Maldivian journalists]] [[dv:{{PAGENAME}}]]

[[Category:Pages for deletion]] [[Image:Imad_Latheef.jpg|right|thumb|Imad Latheef]] '''Imad H. Latheef''' ([[Dhivehi]]: ޢިމާދު ލަޠީފް ) ('''b.''' [[October 27]], [[1966]]), is a professional Maldivian journalist, columnist and a commentator. He is currently the foreign news editor, in [[Haveeru Daily]] news paper in Maldives. ==Early and personal life== Imad Latheef was born in the island of [[Meedhoo]] in [[Addu]] atoll. He married to Siyana Shafeeq in [[1985]], with whom he had a son. In [[1990]] they had a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. Latheef lives with his wife and children in Male’. Before his career as a [[journalist]] began, Latheef filled several private company posts. ==Genealogy== Latheef belongs to the royal houses of both [[Isdhoo dynasty|Isdhoo]] and [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]]. His father Hassan Latheef is the son of Mohamed Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of Ibrahim Manikufaan son of Mohamed Manikufaan (also known as Meedhoo Rahaa) son of Husain Manikufaan son of Prince Ibrahim Manikufan son of [[Sultan Hassan X]] son of [[Sultan Ali VII]] of Isdhoo Dynasty. His mother Wadheefa Ibrahim Didi is the daughter of Ibrahim Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of An-naib Ibrahim Didi son of An-naib Hassan Didi son of An-nabeela Aishath Didi (also known as Dhorhee Didi) daughter of Prince Ibrahim ([[Abdulla]]) Faamuladheyri Kilegefan son of Sultan Muhammad Ghiyasuddin son of Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar II son of Sultan Muzaffar Muhammad Imaduddin II of [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]]. ==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]].Malé English School, Malé. Later he joined Majeediyya School where he did his secondary education. {{maldives-bio-stub}} [[Category:Maldivian people]] [[Category:Maldivian journalists]] [[dv:{{PAGENAME}}]]

[[Category:Pages for deletion]] [[Image:Imad_Latheef.jpg|right|thumb|Imad Latheef]] '''Imad H. Latheef''' ([[Dhivehi]]: ޢިމާދު ލަޠީފް ) ('''b.''' [[October 27]], [[1966]]), is a professional Maldivian journalist, columnist and a commentator. He is currently the foreign news editor, in [[Haveeru Daily]] news paper in Maldives. ==Early and personal life== Imad Latheef was born in the island of [[Meedhoo]] in [[Addu]] atoll. He married to Siyana Shafeeq in [[1985]], with whom he had a son. In [[1990]] they had a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. Latheef lives with his wife and children in Male’. Before his career as a [[journalist]] began, Latheef filled several private company posts. ==Genealogy== Latheef belongs to the royal houses of both [[Isdhoo dynasty|Isdhoo]] and [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]]. His father Hassan Latheef is the son of Mohamed Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of Ibrahim Manikufaan son of Mohamed Manikufaan (also known as Meedhoo Rahaa) son of Husain Manikufaan son of Prince Ibrahim Manikufan son of [[Sultan Hassan X]] son of [[Sultan Ali VII]] of Isdhoo Dynasty. His mother Wadheefa Ibrahim Didi is the daughter of Ibrahim Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of An-naib Ibrahim Didi son of An-naib Hassan Didi son of An-nabeela Aishath Didi (also known as Dhorhee Didi) daughter of Prince Ibrahim ([[Abdulla]]) Faamuladheyri Kilegefan son of Sultan Muhammad Ghiyasuddin son of Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar II son of Sultan Muzaffar Muhammad Imaduddin II of [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]]. ==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]].Malé English School, Malé. Later he joined Majeediyya School where he did his secondary education. ==Career as a journalist== In [[1992]] Latheef joined [[Haveeru Daily]] as a specialized writer on international affairs and international [[sports]]; currently, he is foreign news editor and a staff [[columnist]]. In [[1994]], he joined [[Televison Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from [[1994]] to [[2005]]. He is widely popular among the locals for his efforts to bridge international and local [[soccer]]. ==Awards== * Recipient of the National literature award for distinguished writing in 1999. {{maldives-bio-stub}} [[Category:Maldivian people]] [[Category:Maldivian journalists]] [[dv:{{PAGENAME}}]]

He married to Siyana Shafeeq in [[1985]], with whom he had a son. In [[1990]] they had a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. Latheef lives with his wife and children in Male’. Before his career as a [[journalist]] began, Latheef filled several private company posts. ==Genealogy== Latheef belongs to the royal houses of both [[Isdhoo dynasty|Isdhoo]] and [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]]. His father Hassan Latheef is the son of Mohamed Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of Ibrahim Manikufaan son of Mohamed Manikufaan (also known as Meedhoo Rahaa) son of Husain Manikufaan son of Prince Ibrahim Manikufan son of [[Sultan Hassan X]] son of [[Sultan Ali VII]] of Isdhoo Dynasty. His father Hassan Latheef is the son of Mohamed Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of Ibrahim Manikufaan son of Mohamed Manikufaan (also known as Meedhoo Rahaa) son of Husain Manikufaan son of Prince Ibrahim Manikufan son of [[Sultan Hassan X]] son of [[Sultan Ali VII]] of Isdhoo Dynasty.

==Career as a journalist== In [[1992]] Latheef joined [[Haveeru Daily]] as a specialized writer on international affairs and international [[sports]]; currently, he is foreign news editor and a staff [[columnist]]. In [[1994]], he joined [[Television Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from [[1994]] to [[2005]].

[[Image:Imad_H_Latheef.JPG|right|thumb|Imad Latheef]] '''Imad H. Latheef''' ([[Dhivehi]]: ޢިމާދު ލަޠީފް ) ('''b.''' [[October 27]], [[1966]]), is a Maldivian journalist, columnist and a commentator. He is currently the foreign news editor, in ''[[Haveeru Daily]]'' news paper in Maldives. ==Early and personal life== Imad Latheef was born in the island of [[Meedhoo]] in [[Addu]] atoll. He married to Siyana Shafeeq in [[1985]], with whom he had a son. In [[1990]] they had a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. Latheef lives with his wife and children in Male’.
Before his career as a [[journalist]] began, Latheef filled several private company posts.
==Genealogy==
His father Hassan Latheef is the son of Mohamed Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of Ibrahim Manikufaan son of Mohamed Manikufaan (also known as Meedhoo Rahaa) son of Husain Manikufaan son of Prince Ibrahim Manikufan son of [[Sultan Hassan X]] son of [[Sultan Ali VII]] of Isdhoo Dynasty.
His mother Wadheefa Ibrahim Didi is the daughter of Ibrahim Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of An-naib Ibrahim Didi son of An-naib Hassan Didi son of An-nabeela Aishath Didi (also known as Dhorhee Didi) daughter of Prince Ibrahim ([[Abdulla]]) Faamuladheyri Kilegefan son of Sultan Muhammad Ghiyasuddin son of Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar II son of Sultan Muzaffar Muhammad Imaduddin II of [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]].
==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. Later he joined [[Majeediyya School]] where he did his [[secondary education]].
==Career as a journalist== In [[1992]] Latheef joined [[Haveeru Daily]] as a specialized writer on international affairs and international [[sports]]; currently, he is foreign news editor and a staff [[columnist]]. In [[1994]], he joined [[Television Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from [[1994]] to [[2005]]. Famous for pronouncing names wrongly, in a talk show he once said Ireland's Goalkeeper's name as '''Gay Shiven''' ((its actually Shay Given))
==Awards== * Recipient of the National literature award for distinguished writing in 1999.
==External links== * [http://www.maldivianroots.com Maldivian Roots.com - Online Maldivian Genealogist] * {{dv icon}} [http://haveeru.com.mv/?page=columnists&cat=column&column=44 Latheef's column in Haveeru Online] * {{dv icon}} [http://haveeru.com.mv/?page=columnists Haveeru Daily's Columnists]

[[Image:Imad_H_Latheef.JPG|right|thumb|Imad Latheef]] '''Imad H. Latheef''' ([[Dhivehi]]: ޢިމާދު ލަޠީފް ) ('''b.''' [[October 27]], [[1966]]), is a Maldivian journalist, columnist and a commentator. He is currently the foreign news editor, in ''[[Haveeru Daily]]'' news paper in Maldives. ==Early and personal life== Imad Latheef was born in the island of [[Meedhoo]] in [[Addu]] atoll. He married to Siyana Shafeeq in [[1985]], with whom he had a son. In [[1990]] they had a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. Latheef lives with his wife and children in Male’.
Before his career as a [[journalist]] began, Latheef filled several private company posts.
==Genealogy==
His father Hassan Latheef is the son of Mohamed Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of Ibrahim Manikufaan son of Mohamed Manikufaan (also known as Meedhoo Rahaa) son of Husain Manikufaan son of Prince Ibrahim Manikufan son of [[Sultan Hassan X]] son of [[Sultan Ali VII]] of Isdhoo Dynasty.
His mother Wadheefa Ibrahim Didi is the daughter of Ibrahim Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of An-naib Ibrahim Didi son of An-naib Hassan Didi son of An-nabeela Aishath Didi (also known as Dhorhee Didi) daughter of Prince Ibrahim ([[Abdulla]]) Faamuladheyri Kilegefan son of Sultan Muhammad Ghiyasuddin son of Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar II son of Sultan Muzaffar Muhammad Imaduddin II of [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]].
==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. Later he joined [[Majeediyya School]] where he did his [[secondary education]].
==Career as a journalist== In [[1992]] Latheef joined [[Haveeru Daily]] as a specialized writer on international affairs and international [[sports]]; currently, he is foreign news editor and a staff [[columnist]]. In [[1994]], he joined [[Television Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from [[1994]] to [[2005]].
==Awards== * Recipient of the National literature award for distinguished writing in 1999.

His mother Wadheefa Ibrahim Didi is the daughter of Ibrahim Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of An-naib Ibrahim Didi son of An-naib Hassan Didi son of An-nabeela Aishath Didi (also known as Dhorhee Didi) daughter of Prince Ibrahim ([[Abdulla]]) Faamuladheyri Kilegefan son of Sultan Muhammad Ghiyasuddin son of Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar II son of Sultan Muzaffar Muhammad Imaduddin II of [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]].
==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. Later he joined [[Majeediyya School]] where he did his [[secondary education]].
==Career as a journalist== In [[1992]] Latheef joined [[Haveeru Daily]] as a specialized writer on international affairs and international [[sports]]; currently, he is foreign news editor and a staff [[columnist]]. In [[1994]], he joined [[Television Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from [[1994]] to [[2005]].
==Awards== * Recipient of the National literature award for distinguished writing in 1999.

[[Image:Imad H Latheef.JPG|right|thumb|Imad Latheef]] '''Imad H. Latheef''' ([[Dhivehi]]: ޢިމާދު ލަޠީފް ) ('''b.''' [[October 27]], [[1966]]), is a Maldivian journalist, columnist and a commentator. He is currently the foreign news editor, in ''[[Haveeru Daily]]'' news paper in Maldives. ==Early and personal life== Mr.Latheef was born in the island of [[Meedhoo]] in [[Addu]] atoll. He married Siyana Shafeeq in [[1985]], with whom he had a son. In [[1990]] they had a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. Latheef lives with his wife and children in Male'.
==Genealogy==
His father Hassan Latheef is the son of Mohamed Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of Ibrahim Manikufaan son of Mohamed Manikufaan (also known as Meedhoo Rahaa) son of Husain Manikufaan son of Prince Ibrahim Manikufan son of [[Sultan Hassan X]] son of [[Sultan Ali VII]] of Isdhoo Dynasty.
His mother Wadheefa Ibrahim Didi is the daughter of Ibrahim Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of An-naib Ibrahim Didi son of An-naib Hassan Didi son of An-nabeela Aishath Didi (also known as Dhorhee Didi) daughter of Prince Ibrahim ([[Abdulla]]) Faamuladheyri Kilegefan son of Sultan Muhammad Ghiyasuddin son of Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar II son of Sultan Muzaffar Muhammad Imaduddin II of [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]].
==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. Later he joined [[Majeediyya School]] where he did his [[secondary education]].
==Career as a journalist== In [[1992]] Latheef joined [[Haveeru Daily]] as a specialized writer on international affairs and international [[sports]]; currently, he is foreign news editor and a staff [[columnist]]. In [[1994]], he joined [[Television Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from [[1994]] to [[2005]].
==Awards== * Recipient of the National literature award for distinguished writing in 1999.
==External links== * [http://www.maldivianroots.com Maldivian Roots.com - Online Maldivian Genealogist] * {{dv icon}} [http://haveeru.com.mv/?page=columnists&cat=column&column=44 Latheef's column in Haveeru Online] * {{dv icon}} [http://haveeru.com.mv/?page=columnists Haveeru Daily's Columnists]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Latheef, Imad H.}} [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Maldivian writers]] [[Category:Maldivian journalists]]

His father Hassan Latheef is the son of Mohamed Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of Ibrahim Manikufaan son of Mohamed Manikufaan (also known as Meedhoo Rahaa) son of Husain Manikufaan son of Prince Ibrahim Manikufan son of [[Sultan Hassan X]] son of [[Sultan Ali VII]] of Isdhoo Dynasty.
His mother Wadheefa Ibrahim Didi is the daughter of Ibrahim Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of An-naib Ibrahim Didi son of An-naib Hassan Didi son of An-nabeela Aishath Didi (also known as Dhorhee Didi) daughter of Prince Ibrahim ([[Abdulla]]) Faamuladheyri Kilegefan son of Sultan Muhammad Ghiyasuddin son of Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar II son of Sultan Muzaffar Muhammad Imaduddin II of [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]].
imad is known publicly to be gay and he has connections to former maldivian Dictators Gay brother Abdulla Hameed. He was arrested in 2007 by maldives police in hulhumale for seducing his own sons best friends mother.
==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. Later he joined [[Majeediyya School]] where he did his [[secondary education]]. But he did not complete his secondary education.
==Career as a journalist== In 1992 Latheef joined [[Haveeru Daily]] as a specialized writer on international affairs and international [[sports]]; currently, he is foreign news editor and a staff [[columnist]]. In 1994, he joined [[Television Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from 1994 to 2005.
==Awards== * Recipient of the National literature award for distinguished writing in 1999.

He married Siyana Shafeeq in 1985, with whom he had a son. In 1990 they had a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. Latheef lives with his wife and children in Male'.
==Genealogy==
His father Hassan Latheef is the son of Mohamed Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of Ibrahim Manikufaan son of Mohamed Manikufaan (also known as Meedhoo Rahaa) son of Husain Manikufaan son of Prince Ibrahim Manikufan son of [[Sultan Hassan X]] son of [[Sultan Ali VII]] of Isdhoo Dynasty.

[[Image:Imad H Latheef.JPG|right|thumb|Imad Latheef]] '''Imad H. Latheef''' ([[Dhivehi]]: ޢިމާދު ލަޠީފް ) ('''b.''' [[October 27]], [[1966]]), is a Maldivian journalist, columnist and a commentator. He was the foreign news editor, in ''[[Haveeru Daily]]'' news paper in Maldives. ==Early and personal life== Mr.Latheef was born in the island of [[Meedhoo]] in [[Addu]] atoll. He married Siyana Shafeeq in 1985, with whom he had a son. In 1990 the couple sought a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. Latheef lives with his wife and children in Male'.
==Genealogy==
His father Hassan Latheef is the son of Mohamed Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of Ibrahim Manikufaan son of Mohamed Manikufaan (also known as Meedhoo Rahaa) son of Husain Manikufaan son of Prince Ibrahim Manikufan son of [[Sultan Hassan X]] son of [[Sultan Ali VII]] of Isdhoo Dynasty.
His mother Wadheefa Ibrahim Didi is the daughter of Ibrahim Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of An-naib Ibrahim Didi son of An-naib Hassan Didi son of An-nabeela Aishath Didi (also known as Dhorhee Didi) daughter of Prince Ibrahim ([[Abdulla]]) Faamuladheyri Kilegefan son of Sultan Muhammad Ghiyasuddin son of Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar II son of Sultan Muzaffar Muhammad Imaduddin II of [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]].
==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. Later he joined [[Majeediyya School]] where he did his [[secondary education]]. But he dropped out without completing his secondary education.
==Career as a journalist== In 1992 Latheef joined [[Haveeru Daily]] as a specialized writer on international affairs and international [[sports]]; currently, he is foreign news editor and a staff [[columnist]]. In 1994, he joined [[Television Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from 1994 to 2005. Imad resigned from Haveeru in late 2008, now works as the CEO of a local television known as VTV.
==Awards== * Recipient of the National literature award for distinguished writing in 1999.

[[October 27]], [[1966]]), is a Maldivian journalist, columnist and a commentator. He married Siyana Shafeeq in 1985, with whom he had a son. In 1990 the couple sought a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. ==Genealogy==

Imad resigned from Haveeru in late 2008, now works as the CEO of a local television known as VTV. Imad was arrested for public indecency for having sex with the mother of his son's best friend on hulhumale' beach. Imad has worked for the rights of homosexuals in Maldives and is regarded as a saviour of the gay population. In his golden years in Haveeru as a columnist he wrote against the famous Maldivian superstar Ismail Wajeeh, just because he had a crish on Ismail Wajeeh's then girlfriend Muneera who was aslo a movie star. Imad is proud to say that he is Bisexual, and will continue to be until his death.
==Awards== * Recipient of the National literature award for distinguished writing in 1999.

In 1994, he joined [[Television Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from 1994 to 2005. Imad resigned from Haveeru in late 2008, now works as the CEO of a local television known as VTV.
==Awards== * Recipient of the National literature award for distinguished writing in 1999.

His mother Wadheefa Ibrahim Didi is the daughter of Ibrahim Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of An-naib Ibrahim Didi son of An-naib Hassan Didi son of An-nabeela Aishath Didi (also known as Dhorhee Didi) daughter of Prince Ibrahim ([[Abdulla]]) Faamuladheyri Kilegefan son of Sultan Muhammad Ghiyasuddin son of Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar II son of Sultan Muzaffar Muhammad Imaduddin II of [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]].
==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. Later he joined [[Majeediyya School]] where he did his [[secondary education]]. But he dropped out without completing his secondary education.
==Career as a journalist== In 1992 Latheef joined [[Haveeru Daily]] as a specialized writer on international affairs and international [[sports]]; currently, he is foreign news editor and a staff [[columnist]]. In 1994, he joined [[Television Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from 1994 to 2005. Imad resigned from Haveeru in late 2008, now works as the Head of news department in a local television station known as VTV.
==Awards== * Recipient of the National literature award for distinguished writing in 1999.

His mother Wadheefa Ibrahim Didi is the daughter of Ibrahim Didi, son of Abdullah Didi, son of An-naib Ibrahim Didi, son of An-naib Hassan Didi, son of An-nabeela Aishath Didi (also known as Dhorhee Didi), daughter of [[Prince Abdulla|Prince Ibrahim (Abdulla) Faamuladheyri Kilegefan]], son of Sultan Muhammad Ghiyasuddin, son of Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar II, son of Sultan Muzaffar Muhammad Imaduddin II of [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]].
==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. Later he joined [[Majeediyya School]] where he did his [[secondary education]]. But he dropped out without completing his secondary education.
==Career as a journalist== In 1992 Latheef joined [[Haveeru Daily]] as a specialized writer on international affairs and international [[sports]]; currently, he is foreign news editor and a staff [[columnist]]. In 1994, he joined [[Television Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from 1994 to 2005. Imad resigned from Haveeru in late 2008, now works as the Head of news department in a local television station known as VTV.

revision.comment: /* Genealogy */ specified the country to which the dynasty belongs
revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=July 2011}} <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Imad H Latheef.JPG|right|thumb|Imad Latheef]] --> '''Imad H. Latheef''' ([[Dhilanguage]]: ޢިމާދު ލަޠީފް ) ('''b.''' October 27, 1966), is a Maldivian journalist , columnist and a commentator. He was the foreign news editor, in ''[[Haveeru ]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.haveeru.com.mv/english/details/18980/Steering_committee_of_Maldives_Media_Association_elected|title=Steering committee of Maldives Media Association elected|date=21 October 2007|work=Haveeru Online|accessdate=5 July 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160115054322/http://www.haveeru.com.mv/english/details/18980/Steering_committee_of_Maldives_Media_Association_elected|archive-date=15 January 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref> newspaper in Maldives.
==Early and personal life== Latheef was born in the island of [[Meedhoo (Addu)|Meedhoo]] in [[Addu Atoll|Addu]] atoll. He married Siyana Shafeeq in 1985, with whom he had a son. In 1990 the couple sought a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. Latheef lives with his wife and children in Male'.
==Genealogy==
His father Hassan Latheef is the son of Mohamed Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of Ibrahim Manikufaan son of Mohamed Manikufaan (also known as Meedhoo Rahaa) son of Husain Manikufaan son of Prince Ibrahim Manikufan son of [[Sultan Hassan X]] son of [[Sultan Ali VII]] of Royal Isdhoo Dynasty of [[Maldives]].
His mother Wadheefa Ibrahim Didi is the daughter of Ibrahim Didi, son of Abdullah Didi, son of An-naib Ibrahim Didi, son of An-naib Hassan Didi, son of An-nabeela Aishath Didi (also known as Dhorhee Didi), daughter of [[Prince Abdulla|Prince Ibrahim (Abdulla) Faamuladheyri Kilegefan]], son of Sultan Muhammad Ghiyasuddin, son of Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar II, son of Sultan Muzaffar Muhammad Imaduddin II of Royal [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]] of [[Maldives]].
==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. Later he joined [[Majeediyya School]] where he did his [[secondary education]]. But he dropped out without completing his secondary education.
==Career as a journalist== In 1992 Latheef joined [[Haveeru Daily]] as a specialized writer on international affairs and international [[sports]]; currently, he is foreign news editor and a staff [[columnist]]. In 1994, he joined [[Television Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from 1994 to 2005. Imad resigned from Haveeru in late 2008, now works as the Head of news department in a local television station known as VTV.
==Awards== * Recipient of the National literature award for distinguished writing in 1999.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * Imad Latheef's Personal [https://web.archive.org/web/20090205124523/http://www.imadlatheef.com/ Weblog] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090205171801/http://maldivianroots.com/ Maldivian Roots.com - Online Maldivian Genealogist] * {{in lang|dv}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20060403151819/http://www.haveeru.com.mv/?page=columnists&cat=column&column=44 Latheef's column in Haveeru Online] * {{in lang|dv}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20060403151232/http://www.haveeru.com.mv/?page=columnists Haveeru Daily's Columnists]
{{authority control}}

October 27, 1966), is a Maldivian journalist , columnist and a commentator. He was the foreign news editor, in ''[[Haveeru ]]''<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.haveeru.com.mv/english/details/18980/Steering_committee_of_Maldives_Media_Association_elected|title=Steering committee of Maldives Media Association elected|date=21 October 2007|work=Haveeru Online|accessdate=5 July 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160115054322/http://www.haveeru.com.mv/english/details/18980/Steering_committee_of_Maldives_Media_Association_elected|archive-date=15 January 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref> newspaper in Maldives.
==Early and personal life== Latheef was born in the island of [[Meedhoo (Addu)|Meedhoo]] in [[Addu Atoll|Addu]] atoll. He married Siyana Shafeeq in 1985, with whom he had a son. In 1990 the couple sought a divorce. The following year he married Aminath Saeed, with whom he had a son and a daughter. Latheef lives with his wife and children in Male'.

His father Hassan Latheef is the son of Mohamed Didi son of Abdullah Didi son of Ibrahim Manikufaan son of Mohamed Manikufaan (also known as Meedhoo Rahaa) son of Husain Manikufaan son of Prince Ibrahim Manikufan son of [[Sultan Hassan X]] son of [[Sultan Ali VII]] of Royal Isdhoo Dynasty of [[Maldives]].
His mother Wadheefa Ibrahim Didi is the daughter of Ibrahim Didi, son of Abdullah Didi, son of An-naib Ibrahim Didi, son of An-naib Hassan Didi, son of An-nabeela Aishath Didi (also known as Dhorhee Didi), daughter of [[Prince Abdulla|Prince Ibrahim (Abdulla) Faamuladheyri Kilegefan]], son of Sultan Muhammad Ghiyasuddin, son of Sultan Ibrahim Iskandar II, son of Sultan Muzaffar Muhammad Imaduddin II of Royal [[Dhiyamigili dynasty]] of [[Maldives]].
==Educational background== Latheef began his education at [[Malé English School]], [[Malé]]. Later he joined [[Majeediyya School]] where he did his [[secondary education]]. But he dropped out without completing his secondary education.
==Career as a journalist== In 1992 Latheef joined [[Haveeru Daily]] as a specialized writer on international affairs and international [[sports]]; currently, he is foreign news editor and a staff [[columnist]]. In 1994, he joined [[Television Maldives]] as a sports contributor, presenter and political commentator. Latheef was also a weekly commentator on the National radio from 1994 to 2005. Imad resigned from Haveeru in late 2008, assuming the position of Head of news department in a local television station known as VTV. He is currently a reviewer for Raajje mv.
==Awards== * Recipient of the National literature award for distinguished writing in 1999.
